Holy fuck I love this - I worked at a grocery store where managers/bosses/coworkers bullied the hell out of me. Like my manager and boss would literally yell at me almost daily for things I literally didn't do. Coworkers would blame things on me and make fun of me for being gay. The people who were nice there would ask if I was ok OFTEN. It really got to me and I started hating myself, like really bad...Then once I quit I was like "why did I let these stupid ass people's opinions get to me????? they're not shit compared to me. And these couple of straight men making fun of me for being gay are asking me to suck their dick??? I actually let those dudes' comments get to me???"

I will say tho it can be hard to believe in yourself when you have so many people telling you that you suck. Anyways love this quote

author: @LBYRNTH_
text:
Referencing the different levels of capacity we, as Black people, have for activism is so goddamn relevant to me. I'm no idiot but even just consuming youtube videos meant to teach and relay news burnt my ass out for over a year. "Not everyone xan do everything" and "It's a priviledge to buy all these Black books and be able to read them". Amanda, ma'am... I cannot be an activist. I can barely pay rent consistently in the last year. I had a health emergency last year that took me out for half a year. I am struggling, teetering on and off of depression RIGHT NOW. Bold and italicized. Periodt. Big dot. There's so much ish goin on for normal ahh people like me and we don't got the kind of access, the kind of social and monetary capital you got! Let me rest! I'm tired! Damn!

That being said, I'm really glad this episode encouraged me to give her more grace because how is it that she's so unlikeable but still able to constantly make progressive moves with her peers within the framework of the entertainment industry? That alone was a light switch in my head.  Could it not just be that these systemaic structures that we understand work against Black people are being weaponized against her? An outspoken Black woman? She isn't perfect, sure, but again I needed to give ger a bit more grace because she's also human and just trying to do her work in the service of Black people and progress. Regardless of my feelings on her messaging, I have to respect that.

Edit: ALL THAT BEING SAID... I just watched Jouelzy's video on her and, uhm. There's a lot I wasn't aware of and a lot I now have issues with. I can still respect the resume but, baby, the deeply troubling colorism ish? The odd defenses of men like Jay-Z and her, frankly, harassment of Samira Rice? Somethin ain't right.
